7. These seals are hose-like and attached along the length of the sidewall top edges, enclosing around the hand truck wheel struts and preventing entry of the brine solution into the guide track.
8. When inflated, the elastomer strips perfect a seal around the wheel struts, as well as against itself along the remaining length of the floor track.
9. This invention is particularly useful in meat product chilling chambers, where wheeled hand trucks carry meat products into a sanitary chilling chamber using fluid as a quick cooling agent.
10. The enclosed floor track system ensures that the cooling fluid maintains its sanitary nature and can be reused without incurring the expense of reprocessing it to a sanitary condition.

1. The invention relates to a lock device for preventing a work machine, such as a boom of a backhoe, from being tilted or rotated by its own weight.
2. The lock device includes an engaging member with a hook part and a slot, and an engaged member that can engage with the hook part.
3. A guide member is provided to keep the engaging member at a prescribed position, and a support pin is used to insert into the slot for rotatably and slidably supporting the engaging member.
4. The lock device is easy to operate, prevents damage to the engaging member and engaged member, and reduces the number of parts and assembly processes.

1. The swimming pool vacuum cleaner of the present invention allows for easy adjustment of the vacuum head with respect to the pool bottom to regulate the suction being exerted by the suction head during the pool cleaning operation. The adjustment mechanisms are conveniently located on the top of the vacuum head and can be quickly operated by hand without the need for hand tools.

<summary>
2. The suction head assembly of the invention comprises a generally rectangular, horizontally extending platform having a central portion, longitudinally extending edges, longitudinally spaced end portions, and a plurality of longitudinally spaced, transverse stiffening ribs. The central portion of the platform is provided with an opening and an upwardly extending cylindrical member in communication with the opening. A handle assembly is pivotally interconnected with the platform and is used for moving the suction head across the bottom of the pool.

3. The invention includes first, or outboard roller assemblies connected to the platform proximate each end portion thereof, and second, or inboard roller assemblies interconnected with the platform on either side of the central opening. Each of the outboard roller assemblies includes a pair of spaced apart ribs, or walls, and each of the inboard roller assemblies includes a weight housing having spaced apart ribs, or walls.

4. A highly novel feature of the apparatus of the present invention is the specially configured frame member which is connected to and spans the platform. Each frame member has a central portion and spaced end portions which extend outwardly on either side of the longitudinally extending edges of the platform. The central portion of each frame member is provided with an aperture which is adapted to closely receive a connector means, which is part of the adjustment means of the invention.
</summary>

5. The invention also includes a roller height adjustment device which can be provided in kit form for use in combination with certain types of prior art suction head assemblies. The roller height adjustment device comprises a pair of frames adapted to be positioned over the walls of the housing of the roller construction so as to span the platform. Each frame is of a construction similar to that previously described and includes transversely spaced end portions each having an aperture therethrough. The roller height adjust

1. The present invention is a tool for retrieving wear bushings from oil wells, which are used to protect against excessive wear in seal areas of casing heads and other well head elements.
2. The tool is designed to be used independently of the drill bit, allowing for the removal of the wear bushing even when the drill pipe is lodged in the hole.
3. The tool consists of a sub-unit with a mandrel and a removable lower collar section that can be threaded onto a section of drill pipe.
4. A retriever section, which is slidably movable between the end collars of the sub-unit, is inserted onto the mandrel and has protruding members around its exterior for engaging with an extended J-slot of a wear bushing.
5. The retriever section is prevented from rotational movement by a pair of grooved sections running along the mandrel and an insertion member on the retriever unit.
6. The tool allows for the removal of a damaged wear bushing without the need to retrieve the drill bit, saving time and resources.
7. The tool is easily removable and installable, allowing for quick replacement of the wear bushing during the drilling operation.
8. The tool also allows for vertical play of the retriever unit, preventing damage to the retriever unit or the wear bushing due to excessive weight.
9. The tool can be threadably engaged between any two sections of drill pipe, making it a versatile solution for wear bushing retrieval.
10. The tool is a simple and inexpensive solution to the problems associated with wear bushing retrieval in the present state of the art.

1. The invention describes a vibratory tool used in downhole operations that can selectively allow passage of other tools through it. This tool is designed to dislodge stuck objects, known as fish, from downhole locations and to allow pulling forces to be transmitted from the surface to a fish in a deviated wellbore.
2. Earlier vibratory tools operated on a similar principle, where an overpull is applied to the string supporting the tool, and pressure is applied within the string. A piston then travels against the bias of a spring, stretching the string while compressing the spring. When the force applied by the spring becomes higher than the pressure applied from above, the valve member moves off its seat, relieving the pressure and allowing flow through the tool.
3. However, these earlier designs had limitations, such as not having a central passageway clear for a wireline to run through the tool to determine conditions in the vicinity of the fish. The dump valve that relieved pressure was located in the center of the tool, preventing a clear run through the tool for a wireline or other tools.
4. The new design includes a drop in dart that incorporates the working components of the vibratory tool, allowing for wireline access through the tool body. The dart can be retrieved after the vibration operation, but it requires miniaturization of the vibratory tool's key components, limiting the power delivery of the generated vibrations.
5. The new design also includes a dump valve that is reconfigured into an annular shape, keeping the middle of the tool free and clear for a central passage. This allows a wireline operation through the tool when it is not set up to be in vibratory mode.
6. The mandrel is powered by stacked pistons in the tool body to magnify the delivered power from the vibratory tool. The essential parts of the vibratory tool are in the housing, and only the delivery of the plug is required to initiate operations.
7. The tool can be run in a manner where high amplitude low-frequency oscillating forces are delivered to the stuck fish without impacts of the pistons on the housing. The tool can also be operated to apply up oscillating forces with or without impacts, depending on how the tool is operated by rig personnel.
8. The tool has an outer body with a lower end attached to a stuck object or fish. Within the outer body, and extending

1. The present invention describes a precast concrete retaining wall system with a face panel and a base, both with integral counterforts for added support and stability. The face panel and counterfort are connected to the base using a shear key filled with grout. This system eliminates the need for temporary shoring and allows for taller walls and shorter bases, reducing installation and transportation costs.
2. The counterforts can have openings for drainage to limit pressure on the wall and improve stability. Reinforcing bars (rebar) can be cast within the counterfort and base for additional strength. The base is generally a rectangular or trapezoidal platform, precast concrete, and can have openings to accept downward-extending rebar ends from the counterfort.
3. The connection between the face panel and base is made by inserting an end of a piece of rebar of one module into an opening in the other module and then sealing the connection with grout. This arrangement allows for quick and easy installation with no temporary shoring required.
4. In case of poor soil conditions, H-piles can be driven into the ground and the base set on top of these piles for added stability. A pocket can be created in the base to allow the pile to extend up into the base, and the connection can be filled with grout.
5. The invention also describes a method for creating a cast-in-place vehicle impact barrier on top of or behind the wall by exposing rebar on the face or rear surface of the face panel and casting concrete around it. Alternatively, a pre-manufactured, pre-cast barrier can be formed integrally with the face at the factory.

1. The invention is a down hole heating system to improve the flow of oil or gas in wells by melting paraffin and reducing oil viscosity.
2. The system includes production tubing, a heat insulating packer, perforated tubing, a stainless steel tubing collar, and a heating unit.
3. The heating unit contains electrical resistance heater rods, and the heat is contained within the desired zone using the packer and collars.
4. The system focuses heat on the production formation itself, allowing oil and paraffin to flow to the well bore for pumping.
5. The internal connection of the heating unit is impenetrably shielded from pressures and hostile chemical agents in the well bore.
6. The method for using the system includes installing the heating unit with shielded electrical connections and heat-retaining elements to focus heat on the producing formation.

1. The invention relates to a mechanism for installing and retrieving downhole objects in wells, specifically designed to connect to and disconnect from downhole objects or "fish" that may become stuck or lost in a wellbore. This mechanism is an improvement on U.S. Pat. No. 4,061,389 and is applicable to wire line operations. Downhole devices, such as those used for controlling well operations, often have API Standard fishing necks with undercut shoulders for standard installation and retrieval tools. However, these fishing necks can become corroded or eroded, leaving only a stub pipe without the usual undercut shoulder. In such cases, an overshot type grappling device with internal teeth can be used to establish a gripping relation with the worn fishing neck. The problem with such tools is that disconnection from the worn fishing neck can be difficult, often requiring substantial jarring or violent mechanical movement. The invention aims to provide a mechanism that can easily and reliably connect to and disconnect from downhole objects.
2. The invention features an expandable collet type device for establishing internal connection with an object to be pulled from the wellbore. The collet structure is part of an outer tubular body having an inner body structure disposed in movable relation therein. Telescoping movement of the inner and outer body structures causes the overshot or spear to selectively move into gripping relationship with the object that is to be removed from the wellbore. The tubular outer body is secured about the inner body by means of a catch mechanism having a locking position and an unlocking position, depending on the relative positions of the inner and outer body structures. A pin structure forming a part of the catch mechanism is selectively positioned within pin receiving grooves and a control spring is employed to ensure that the pin alternately enters one or the other of a pair of unlocking or locking grooves each time the inner and outer body structures are cycled linearly relative to one another.
3. The invention also includes an alternative embodiment adapted for overshot type grappling and removal of objects from well bores. This embodiment features an inner body structure that is formed to define a portion of a locking mandrel and an externally threaded lower portion that is adapted to receive the internally threaded portion of a piston and guide element. The piston and guide element is formed to define an outer cyl
1. The present application claims priority to co-pending Mexico patent application Ser. Nos. MX/a/2011/005499 and MX/a/2

1. The invention is related to ladder attachments that provide lateral stability, prevent damage to the work surface, and prevent slipping or sliding.
2. The ladder attachment includes a brace with an extension arm and a U-bolt that secures the brace to the ladder rung. A resilient pad assembly is pivotally connected to the extension arm to provide a non-slip gripping portion that grips the work surface without damaging it.
3. The large contact area brace assemblies attached to the siderails of the ladder increase the contact area with the work surface, improving lateral stability and preventing damage to the work surface. The brace assemblies can be adjusted to accommodate different sizes of ladders.
4. The resilient pad assembly can pivot horizontally or vertically, allowing the ladder to straddle corners and providing stability on both flat and corner work surfaces. The clamp exerts a force against the siderail to prevent any motion of the arm toward or away from the siderail.
5. The construction of the brace assembly may be of heavier gauge material or use alternative bolt arrangements to resist forces tending to move the arm toward the center of the ladder. These modifications can be useful in less substantial ladders where there is a limit on the amount the U-bolt can be torqued.
6. The ladder attachment provides a non-slip gripping portion, increases the contact area of the ladder with the work surface, improves lateral stability, and allows the ladder to straddle corners, all while preventing damage to the work surface. The invention can be modified and adapted to various situations and materials without departing from the essential teachings of the present invention.

1. The present invention pertains to a collated nail strip formed with a debris-free plastic material for use in a fastener driving tool. Collated nails are assembled in strips that are inserted into a magazine of the tool, with the nails held parallel to one another in a staggered or stepped manner. Presently known collated nails are assembled using tape strips or an extruded plastic material, but these methods can result in debris and shattering of the plastic material as the nails are driven into the workpiece.
2. The invention aims to reduce the tendency for the plastic to generate debris and minimize the amount of plastic that separates from the nail shank. This is achieved through the use of a collation system that reduces the tendency for the nail strip to corrugate or advance on itself in the tool magazine, minimizes the strip's flexibility, and maximizes the adhesion of the plastic to the nail shanks. The system is also designed to permit the collation to be coiled for use in driving tools that accept collations in this manner.
3. The fastener assembly includes a row of fasteners arranged parallel to each other, with a collation system formed from a plastic material that is molded onto and adhered to the fasteners. The plastic material defines a collar portion that captures or at least substantially encircles the fastener shank and a connecting portion extending between and connecting adjacent collar portions. The plastic material is formulated from an adhesive polymer such as a polyolefin, a polyolefin blend, an epoxy, or the like. When the fastener is driven from the driving tool, the collar portion remains adhered to the fastener such that the collar portion penetrates the substrate with the fastener.
4. The connecting portion can be formed as a bridge and a rib in a cruciform shape, with the rib formed parallel to the collation or at an angle. Alternatively, the connecting portion can have an embossed pattern formed therein. The collation system includes upper and lower plastic moldings adhered to the fasteners, with the lower molding formed on the shank of the fastener within the lower half and preferably within about ½ inch of the tip of the fastener.
5. The method for making a fastener assembly includes arranging a plurality of fasteners in a row parallel to one another, preheating the

1. The invention is a nozzle for applying sealants such as silicones, useful in various industries including aviation, automotive, naval, railway, and robotics. 
2. The nozzle has a bell or hood lower section and an injection button, and is designed to facilitate the injection of sealants in multiple industrial applications. 
3. The bell-shaped tip of the nozzle facilitates the encapsulation of rivets or screws, particularly in the aeronautical industry, and the injection button has a special design with channels and orifices for carrying out sealing operations with greater accuracy.
4. The button section improves the encapsulation and provides an optimum sealing of rivets and nuts, and allows the user to apply sealant operations both manually and by automated sealant injection machines.
5. The bell or hood lower section of the nozzle may be used in the aviation industry and the automotive, naval, railway and robotics industries.
6. The nozzle comprises a main elongated hollow body having a truncated cone shape, a first end with a wider diameter, and a second end with a narrower diameter.
7. The first end of the nozzle has a connecting hollow round section with a threaded exterior surface, which allows the nozzle to be connected to a silicone or similar sealant cartridge or injection machine.
8. The second end of the nozzle has a bell or hood shaped section, physically connected to the main elongated body, and sized to encapsulate rivets or nuts in order to cover them completely with the sealing material.
9. The injection button is connected to the peripheral annular flanged section of the bell-shaped section, and comprises a circular main body and a peripheral groove section around the end of the main body.
10. The annular flanged section of the bell shaped section cooperatively matches with the peripheral groove of the injection button, allowing a strong and firm non-permanent connection or coupling of the button to the bell shaped section.

1. The invention describes a position sensor that modifies an unconditioned sensing signal from a transducer into a conditioned sensing signal by removing unneeded power, which can be used for multiplexing multiple sensors with a minimum number of wires and energy required from each sensor monitoring system.
2. A window reference circuit constantly compares a desired conditioned sensor signal output to an existing conditioned sensor signal output and adjusts the conditioned sensor signal output if it is above a preset high reference signal or below a preset low reference signal.
3. An error correction generator, which includes a comparator, controller, and signal processor, provides an error correction signal to the waveform generator to modify the unconditioned sensing signal. The error correction generator determines and eliminates strong static signals and error signals that do not deliver information about the position of an object being sensed.
4. The error correction generator constantly compares the value of the conditioned sensing signal to a desired minimum value and generates a correction signal that is subtracted from the offset and error signal to deliver a sensor signal output that is close to a desired minimum value.
5. The signal processor generates a relatively small reference signal that is large enough to eliminate small values of drift in a negative going direction yet is small enough not to generate a significant amount of signal due to the discrete nature of calibration voltages from a DAC and counter combination employed thereby.
6. The error correction generator generates a relatively large reference signal that substantially exceeds the largest voltage encountered by the sensor as an object being monitored moves its maximum amount, allowing rapid recalibration due to sudden changes in an offset voltage caused by rapid temperature or other changes.

1. The document describes a desmodromic valve actuation system for intake and exhaust function of a four-stroke piston in internal combustion engines, which eliminates the need for springs used in conventional systems.
2. The system uses a timing belt to connect the engine crankshaft to a camshaft, which has cams for each intake and exhaust valve in each cylinder.
3. The cams displace the valves inwardly to open either the intake or exhaust port, and are incapable of closing the port openings.
4. Springs, compressed when the cams open a port, provide the force to close the port, while the cam controls the valve movement.
5. The system aims to improve fuel efficiency by controlling the amount of air/gas mixture entering each piston and the ability to close any number of cylinders while the engine is performing.
6. The system can significantly reduce gas consumption of an internal combustion engine by efficiently and effectively controlling valve port openness in concert with the requirements of the operation of a vehicle.
7. The system can be computer-controlled, offering smooth sensitive control of the engine performance and in turn the automobile.
8. The system is simplified in nature, more effective in controlling the percentage opening of valve ports, and eliminates the necessity of springs in the functioning of valves as found in present-day automotive internal combustion engines.

1. The text describes an aquarium lighting system using LEDs with a housing having a top side and a bottom side, and a lighting control region on the bottom side. The lighting control region includes at least two control channels for controlling different colors of light and a neutral channel. Light-emitting modules are sized and configured to be coupled to the lighting control region and have electrical connectors that couple to the control channels.
2. The system includes switches on the housing that control the first control channel and the second control channel. The switches can be on/off switches, dimmer switches, or a three-way switch that controls both channels. The light-emitting modules can be added or removed from the lighting control region as desired.
3. Each light-emitting module includes a bottom side that faces the interior of the aquarium, and a top, connection side that faces the lighting control area. The bottom side includes LEDs that emit white or blue light, and the connection side includes electrical connectors that couple to the control channels.
4. The system allows for adjusting the color temperature output of the aquarium by controlling the intensity of the white and blue light. The two channel design enables variable functionality and output options in a small and focused footprint.
5. The light-emitting modules can include narrow incident angle LEDs, wide angle LEDs, or optical elements that change angles of the light emitted from the LEDs, diffuse the light, and/or focus the light. The optical elements can be removable while the light element is in place.
6. The system can include radio frequency (RF) or other communication/control hardware so as to be controlled remotely by a remote control. The module includes six RGB LEDs that blend red, green, and blue light to create a wide range of colors within the aquarium. The remote control functions include on/off, increase/decrease intensity, color selection, reset, and auto mode.

1. The present invention concerns a cooled flow deflection apparatus for a fluid-flow machine operating at high temperatures.
2. Current flow deflection apparatuses, such as stator or rotor blades in a gas turbine, require internal cooling channels to reduce metal temperature.
3. The invention proposes using separate inserts for the separating walls, which are inserted and secured in the apparatus, rather than casting them together.
4. This approach reduces material in the transitional region from the hot-gas wall to the separating wall, eliminates thermal stresses, and allows for easier cooling system adjustments.
5. A preferred embodiment features a hollow casting with integrally formed rails for inserting and sealing the separating walls.
6. In this embodiment, the inserted separating walls can be connected by an integral material joint for added security.
7. The invention is particularly advantageous for complex geometries, such as blades in a gas turbine, and for rotor blades rotating at high speed.
8. The separating walls can be straight or bent into a U-shape for connecting cooling channels with deflection devices.

1. The system of the present invention is a fuel delivery control system for a vehicle that can be switched between automatic and manual control. The system comprises a control unit that receives signals indicating accelerator pedal position and throttle valve position, and processes these signals to automatically set the throttle position for optimum vehicle performance. The control unit also provides an output signal that controls a clutch, which connects the accelerator pedal directly to the throttle valve when manual control is desired.

2. During manual control, the vehicle driver has full control of the vehicle. Changing control from automatic to manual does not occur until the throttle valve is moved to a predetermined position or is positioned to match what is commanded by the accelerator pedal, preventing the vehicle from lurching forward or stalling when control is shifted.

3. The control system of the present invention may be used in conjunction with a system for controlling the operation of a continuously variable transmission. At high transmission ratios, it is desirable to manually control the throttle valve position while at low transmission ratios, automatic control is preferred. The control unit may be programmed to detect the transmission ratio and switch to the optimum control mode for the throttle.

1. The invention described is a waste fuel burner designed to efficiently burn particulate-laden gas or waste fuels such as wood waste, producing minimal quantities of particulate emissions and little slag or clinkers.
2. The burner forms a conical pile of waste fuel, with preheated underfire air percolating up through the pile to dry and gasify the fuel, and volatile gases driven off the pile are partially oxidized in a primary combustion chamber.
3. The primary combustion chamber maintains a steady temperature lower than the ash fusion temperature, and a flame holder forces volatile gases and any entrained particulate matter out to the walls of the throat for centrifugal separation.
4. Volatile gases move into a secondary combustion chamber where secondary combustion air is introduced for complete combustion, and the secondary air is directed tangentially to regulate the flame position.
5. The primary and secondary chambers can be added to any source of dirty particulate-laden combustible gas to burn the gas and remove particulate for meeting environmental emission standards.
6. The burner includes a primary combustion chamber lined with refractory material and spaced from an outer metallic shell by an air cooling passage.
7. Fuel is fed from a hopper by a conveyor into the form of a conical pile, and preheated underfire combustion air is directed into two chambers to percolate or blow up through the pile.
8. High pressure swirl air is admitted through tuyeres at an angle to the side wall, generating centrifugal forces that drive heavier non-combusted materials to the outer wall.
9. Secondary combustion air is introduced at tuyeres in the secondary combustion chamber, which are all adjustable to assist in positioning the flame for various types of fuels and moisture contents.
10. The volatile gas passing through the discharge from the primary chamber works its way past an air cooled horizontal, disc shaped flame holder, causing the primary chamber gases to flow radially outward and around the flame holder.

1. The invention describes an evaporative cooler system that uses a heat exchanger to separate evaporating water from the cooling air stream, achieving sensible cooling while drawing at least a major portion of the working air from the room to be cooled for maximum efficiency.
2. The system can include variations such as recirculation of return air for quicker cooling, bypass of cooled air for lower temperature, and a hybrid system that combines evaporative cooling with a vapor compression refrigeration unit for further cooling and dehumidification.

1. The document describes a fluid pump system for pumping liquids at high volumetric flow rates and pressures, particularly for pumping liquid manure from a reservoir. The system includes multiple pump heads, each with a housing containing an impeller, and a drive structure that commonly drives the impellers.
2. The pump heads are connected in series, with fluid flowing from one pump head into the next. Each pump head has an inlet for drawing fluid from outside the housing and at least two fluid conduits that combine the fluid flow before exiting the pump head.
3. The drive structure may comprise one or more drive shafts on which the impellers are mounted, and connectors that transmit rotational motion from one drive shaft to another. The connectors may extend out from the pump heads and be partially disposed in the fluid flow path between the pump heads.
4. The pump heads are disposed in series so that fluid flows sequentially through each pump head of the pump, and are connected to provide rigidity and a fluid seal between the pump heads. The pump heads may be removably connected or may be formed in a unitary structure.
5. The fluid pump system cannot be constructed by simply stacking known pumps together, as the initial and final pump heads have different design features to permit fluid flow from one pump head to the other. Intermediate pump heads have design features of both the initial and final pump heads to permit cooperation with neighboring pump heads.
6. The system may be mounted on a support structure such as a wheeled boom, a hitching assembly, or a trailer, which permits operation of the pump at a fluid reservoir.
7. The system is designed for modularity, allowing for easy repair and maintenance, and the inclusion of more pump heads to increase the operating pressure of the pump.

1. This invention is about an engine with a modular engine compression release brake system that has engine brakes for a portion of the engine cylinders, which is less than all of them.
2. The engine has a low pressure reservoir, a high pressure pump, a high pressure manifold, and a hydraulic system that uses oil from the low pressure reservoir.
3. The engine also has an electronic control module that controls various engine functions, including fuel injection timing and engine compression release brake timing.
4. Each cylinder in the engine has a piston that moves up and down, creating four strokes: intake, compression, power, and exhaust.
5. A portion of the cylinders have hydraulically actuated engine compression release brakes that are connected to the exhaust valve.
6. The engine brakes have a brake body, an electrical actuator, a valve member, a spool valve member, and a piston.
7. The engine brakes work by using high pressure fluid to move the piston, which then pushes on the exhaust valve actuator to open the exhaust valve.
8. The engine control module determines if engine braking is needed and how much braking horsepower is required.
9. The engine brakes are modular, allowing customers to choose the amount of braking horsepower they need for a specific application.

1. The invention describes a link assembly between an engine and a gearbox, with a male link and a female link that can translate relative to each other to form a radial interface that dampens translation.
2. A pin releasably couples the male and female links to retain them, and can shear during extreme loads to allow a permitted range of motion and absorb shocks.
3. The gearbox assembly includes a gearbox and the link assembly, and can be used in aircraft gas turbine engines to transmit torque to peripheral loads.
4. Seal and mounting links collectively constrain the gearbox with respect to the engine in six degrees of freedom, without over-constraining it.
5. The mounting link includes a female link, a male link, and a pin, and can rigidly constrain one degree of freedom between the engine and the gearbox.
6. During extreme loads, the pin can shear to allow a permitted range of motion and absorb shocks, while the interface between the female and male links dampens the relative motion.
7. The female link includes a link mounting end and a link interface end with a cavity to receive the male link.
8. The male link is attached to the corresponding component that the female link is not attached to, and includes a link mounting end and a link interface end that is received by the female link.
9. The pin selectively prevents the relative translation of the female and male links, and can be designed to shear at a known load magnitude.
10. After the pin shears, the female and male links are allowed to translate relative to each other, providing coulomb damping to dissipate energy created by the translation.

1. The invention describes an archery equipment that includes a point cap, point adaptor, nock cap, and balance pin, with the point cap and balance pin being adjustable in weight to achieve perfect balance.
2. The point cap and adaptor are made of hardened steel and lightweight material respectively, and are attached to the arrow shaft using epoxy, providing additional support and fluid communication.
3. The balance pin is made of heavy, soft metal and is affixed to the arrow shaft or point cap, allowing adjustment of point weight and prevention of movement or vibration.

1. The Small Arms Firing Effect Simulator (SAFES) is an electronically controlled pyrotechnic sound and flash simulator for military weapons training, specifically designed for the M16 rifle. 
2. The SAFES circuitry consists of a bolt interface, trigger interface, oscillator control, 500 Hertz oscillator, 10 Hertz oscillator, firing counter, firing decoder, firing control, firing sensors, and a MILES interface.
3. The bolt interface provides a realistic simulation of operator actions during live firing, while the trigger interface detects the trigger pull and initiates the firing sequence.
4. The oscillator control, 500 Hertz oscillator, and 10 Hertz oscillator regulate the timing and sequence of the firing events.
5. The firing counter and decoder manage the count and decoding of the firing events, while the firing control handles the ignition of the pyrotechnic charges.
6. The SAFES system interfaces with the weapon's trigger, bolt, and ejection port, and is designed to resemble an M16 magazine clip for enhanced realism during training exercises.

1. The present invention is an air intake device for an internal combustion engine, comprising a tank, a first pipe, a second pipe, and a control valve. The tank provides a constant volume and is extended along the intake pipe. The first and second pipes interconnect the tank with the air intake passage at different locations, with the second passage having a smaller cross-sectional area than the first passage. The control valve is disposed in the first passage and is actuated by an actuator responsive to an engine operating condition.

* The cross-sectional area of the first passage is equal to or larger than that of the intake passage, and the cross-sectional area of the second passage is substantially equal to or smaller than about one-tenth that of the first passage.
* The second passage opens to the air intake passage at a location nearer the air cleaner than the location where the first passage opens to the air intake passage.

2. The control valve is controlled to create a new compound curve comprising each peak portion of the curves A and B, thereby improving engine performance.

* The length from the open end of the air inlet pipe to the air cleaner is preferably 10 cm, but this results in an increase in the air intake noise.
* The provision of the narrow passage of the pipe 6 interconnecting the tank 4 with the intake pipe 2 constitutes a resonator rather than a device to influence the dynamic efficiency.

3. The operation of the valve 7 is determined by the engine speed and load.

* The valve 7 is turned to open or to close at engine speed N X and N Y where the two curves A and B intersect.
* The valve 7 is preferably closed at any engine speed when the load is below the line n.
* When the load is above the line n, the valve 7 is operated in a manner as shown in FIG. 2.

4. The valve operating conditions can be stored as a map in the control circuit, which produces a control signal for the solenoid valve and thus the control valve based on the engine speed sensor and the throttle position sensor.

* The engine load can be detected by the position of the throttle valve or by other means, such as

1. The invention describes a two-part bracket system, including a stationary bracket and an adjustable bracket, designed for mounting speakers or other objects on surfaces or poles. The system is easy to install by a single person and allows for directional positioning of the mounted object.
2. The stationary bracket can be attached to a wall or other flat surface, or to a pole using a specialized bracket and securing rods. The adjustable bracket can be connected to the object to be mounted in a temporary or final position, using axel screws and flexible wings. The system is suitable for various objects, such as loudspeakers, lighting, signage, and video cameras.

1. The invention describes a modular burner system for heat-utilizing appliances, which includes a burner with a fuel holder, a housing, an air inlet, a constricted exhaust outlet, and an outer shroud that channels products of combustion towards the exhaust outlet to concentrate heat.
2. The system also includes an ash pan that can store water to extinguish burning embers, and an air damper or ash pan that serves as an air damper to control the volume of air flow through the air inlet.
3. The system further comprises at least one leg that supports the burner above the ground, a cover that prevents inadvertent ingress of objects and emissions of live embers, and a grill with openings for hot gases to pass through.
4. A coupling is provided for detachably coupling a modular heat-utilizing appliance, such as a cooker, to the burner.
5. The system may also include a pyrolyzer that includes a substantially air-tight heating chamber for pyrolyzing carboniferous materials and a condenser for condensing vaporized liquid products of pyrolysis conducted to the condenser.

1. The invention aims to improve combustion efficiency and cooling characteristics in rotary internal combustion engines, minimizing thermal distortion and structural failure risks.
2. The design features a housing structure that facilitates circumferential cooling flow while allowing spark plug bosses to be inserted, with minimal thermal distortion in the spark plug boss zones.
3. A peripheral cooling circuit is defined with separate flow paths for releasing boiling vapor from multiple spark plug bosses, reducing heat transfer issues.
4. The housing structure is designed to increase the heat transfer coefficient of the cooling circuit at the spark plug boss zone by at least 20% over prior art capabilities.
5. Plug bosses are interposed in a circumferential cooling flow passageway, staggered with respect to the direction of flow, promoting relatively close in-line arrangement of the spark plug terminals.
6. A predetermined and limited offset from a line extending between the spark plug terminals ensures adequate heat extraction and flame propagation.
7. Flow diverters or controllers between the spark plug bosses maintain a controlled flow regime and strengthen the housing structure.
8. Staggered spark plug bosses improve coolant performance around each boss, reducing locally high thermal conditions and enhancing heat transfer during boiling heat transfer.

1. The invention describes a method and system for minimizing flow disturbance caused by the closing and reopening of turbine control valves during periodic operational testing. The method uses control valve positions as feedback to adjust the flow through parallel control valves and compensate for the closure and reopening of turbine control valves. This results in reduced steam boiler pressure changes and turbine power changes during testing.
2. The system includes a test compensation circuit that uses a test compensation array and a sample and hold circuit to provide flow compensation for the three input control valves not under test. The flow compensation is based on the mass flow being demanded and the stem lift of the valve being controlled. A lift flow array and a divider circuit are used to provide a varying flow demand signal for the other three input control valves not under test.
3. The output of the divider circuit is then fed into a summing circuit which also receives a reference signal with a constant value of “1”. The output from the divider circuit is subtracted in the summing circuit from the fixed constant of “1” to produce an output of “0” that is fed into a multiplier circuit of the valves not being tested. The output of the summing circuit increases from 0 to 1 as the tested valve is closed and then reopened.
4. The output of the multiplier circuit is fed into a select circuit which also receives a reference signal with a constant value of “0” and a third signal from the valve test control circuit. The select circuit will output the value of the multiplier circuit only when a valve, other than itself, is being tested. The overall control strategy requires control of pressure ahead of the valves using a proportional regulator.
5. The control system of the present invention reduced the pressure excursion of the turbine inlet main (throttle) steam pressure by 95% when compared to a system without flow compensation. The invention is not limited to the disclosed embodiment and is intended to cover various modifications and equivalent arrangements included within the spirit and scope of the appended claims.
1. The invention is a mixing valve for an aircraft cleaning apparatus that combines fluids from two separate sources into one mixture, with a solution ranging from 0% inlet A fluid, 1

1. The invention describes a method and arrangement for compressing and cooling natural gas in a compressor station for a gas pipeline, particularly in permanent frost areas.
2. The method involves compressing the gas to a higher pressure, cooling it by heat exchange, and then expanding it to a lower pressure to achieve further cooling.
3. The arrangement includes a compressor, heat exchanger, valve-controlled pipelines, and control units, with an electronic control and expanding unit added to carry out the method.
4. The invention aims to reduce investments and operation risk by eliminating the need for expensive re-cooling plants and their associated safety risks.

1. The text describes a cooling fan assembly for forced air cooling in various applications, such as computers or heat-generating systems. The assembly includes a motor, a fan blade, and motor control components (<summary>
2. The motor is typically electrical but can be hydraulic, pneumatic, or otherwise, and is housed in a non-rotatable housing coupled to a motor carrier with mounting legs.
3. The mounting legs have resilient leg portions that engage with recesses in a panel, using spring members to urge the motor carrier away from the panel and prevent disengagement due to vibrational forces.
4. To install the assembly, the user positions the turned-out portions of the resilient legs into the enlarged opening regions of the recesses, with the spring members uncompressed.
5. A compressive and rotating force is then applied to compress the spring members and reposition the resilient legs into smaller openings, capturing each leg portion pair within its respectively associated residual opening.
6. The spring member remains compressed in the fully installed position, urging the turned-out portions of the resilient leg portions against the exterior surface of the panel.
7. The described invention can have various modifications or additions, such as using different types of spring members or devices capable of exerting an urging force between the cooling fan assembly and the panel. </summary>

1. Spacecraft structures often use lightweight composite materials that have low damping and vibration dissipation characteristics, which can cause high vibration levels and compromise the functionality of instruments mounted on precision kinematic mounts (KMs). This is because KMs have very little inherent damping, which can amplify flight loads to the mounted instrument.
2. The present invention aims to provide kinematic mounts with novel damping features and a passive energy dissipating mechanism to protect the instrument from potentially damaging flight loads. The invention can be incorporated on existing KM structures and uses six identical strut elements to reduce manufacturing complexity and costs.
3. The invention slightly rearranges the six strut configuration to approximately uncouple the mount suspension modes, thus further improving KM performance. The kinematic mounts achieve modal vibration tests on coupon sample mounts that yield modal damping values from 5-17% of critical damping, which are at least one to two orders of magnitude greater damping than existing designs.
4. The invention can be applied to a large number of precision or optical instruments/sensors where alignment stability is important. The damping mechanism may be provided at machined hinge or flexure locations of the mounts, and the damping materials introduce a damping mechanism into the mount suspension modes, thus dissipating into heat and reducing the high energy disturbances to the instrument.

1. The invention describes an oil shear type clutch unit for large power transmission requirements, such as in aircraft catapult systems, that can apply strong coupling forces while maintaining high control accuracy and minimizing residual drag.
2. The clutch unit comprises an input shaft, an output shaft, a plurality of clutch plates connected to one shaft, and a plurality of clutch discs interleaved with the plates and connected to the other shaft.
3. Each clutch disc consists of arcuate segments in a circumferential arrangement, with separate means for closing the gap between each disc and its adjacent plates through piston and cylinder means connected to the clutch plates on opposite sides.
4. The clutch unit also features auxiliary fluid pressure control means for urging the clutch plates to retract from the clutch discs, and removable fastener means for holding the supporting means of the clutch disc segments in position, allowing for easy replacement of the segments.

1. The text describes an engine system with multiple cylinders, including combustion cylinders and expansion cylinders, which are arranged in various configurations to optimize the engine's performance and efficiency. The system includes a water injection process that cools the exhaust gas and expands it to drive the expansion cylinder piston. The system also includes a multi-stage cascade of expansion cylinders, which allows for the recapture of heat and energy before exhausting to the atmosphere. The system aims to minimize heat loss to the radiator, exhaust, and convection, and to maximize the energy output of the engine.
2. The system includes a water cooling system that maintains the temperature of the combustion cylinders at a lower level than the working temperature of the liquid coolant. The cooling system can be maintained as a closed circuit and separate from the water injection. The system also includes a control that can modulate the ignition timing to achieve tight control over the temperature of the combustion cylinder and to transfer some of the heat load to the expansion cylinders.
3. The system includes a water recovery system that ensures that the source of water will be largely recycled, and that an unduly large water tank will not be necessary. The expansion cylinders may be provided in sufficient numbers to bring the final exhaust to a low temperature, say below 500° F., and in a preferred embodiment, at or below 212° F. The engines may achieve steady-state thermal-to-mechanical efficiencies that are in the range of 94-96%. The system also includes components with surface materials chosen to catalyze certain desirable reactions for the benefit of reduced exhaust emissions.

1. The invention relates to a fabrication method for steel plates or blanks that are coated, welded, and heat-treated to produce parts with high mechanical strength, high impact resistance, and good corrosion resistance. This method is an improvement on the process disclosed in patent EP 0971044, which forms a surface alloy by interdiffusion between the steel and aluminum coating to prevent decarburization and oxidation during heat treatment.

2. The invention addresses the issue of intermetallic areas forming within welded assemblies due to the initial surface metal coating melting during butt-welding. These intermetallic areas reduce the overall deformability of the welded joints and are a source of rupture under static or dynamic conditions. The invention aims to eliminate these intermetallic areas while maintaining good corrosion resistance in the welded and heat-treated parts.

3. The proposed solution is a plate consisting of a steel substrate and a precoat, which is an alloy of aluminum or based on aluminum, topped by a metal alloy layer. On at least one precoated face of the plate, an area situated at the periphery of the plate has the metal alloy layer removed. This area can be produced by partly eliminating the metal alloy layer on the precoated face by brushing or using a laser beam.

4. A welded blank is obtained by butt-welding at least two plates with the welded joint produced on the edge contiguous with the area from which the metal alloy has been removed. A part is then obtained by heat treatment and deformation of the welded blank, with the precoat being converted throughout its thickness into an intermetallic alloy compound that provides protection against corrosion and decarburization of the steel substrate.

5. The invention also provides a method for fabricating a precoated steel plate, which includes coating a steel plate to obtain a precoat with an intermetallic alloy layer topped by a metal alloy layer, and removing the metal alloy layer in an area not totally contiguous with the periphery of the plate before cutting the plate in a plane so that the area from which the metal alloy has been removed is at the periphery of the cut plate. This method ensures

1. The invention is a Supervisory Control And Data Acquisition (SCADA) system for remotely controlling a mobile structure that recovers energy from severe weather patterns.
2. The system uses an algorithm that optimizes efficiency by accounting for data from weather observations and sensors on the mobile structure.
3. The algorithm is used to navigate a sailing vessel optimized to reduce drag while responding to wind and water velocity vectors.
4. The SCADA system includes computer servers that gather data from various sources, including GPS systems, weather satellite systems, and geographic and weather data resources.
5. The system can be used to remotely control any system that exploits energy from weather patterns, such as wind energy, water current or wave energy, or energy from electrical storms.
6. The system enables a mobile system to automatically track environmental conditions hazardous to humans, allowing for safe and cost-effective energy extraction.
7. The system can also be used for logistics-only purposes, guiding navigation of vessels past weather patterns.
8. The system comprises a mobile structure, a central service facility, and a communication system for transmitting data between the two.
9. The system uses a graphical user interface that allows remote humans to interact with and choose mission-critical navigation plans.

1. The invention describes a rolling body guide cage produced from at least one ring element and several guide structures arranged in succession in the circumferential direction, with each guide structure designed to guide rolling bodies. The method for manufacturing such a rolling body guide cage is also covered.
2. The prior art has a ball bearing cage composed of two axially profiled ring elements with spherical cap pockets arranged in succession in the circumferential direction. These pockets are connected via bridge portions and formed by punching out ring elements from a sheet metal material.
3. A disadvantage of this method is the generation of a large amount of waste material during the punching process. The invention aims to reduce production costs in the manufacture of rolling body guide cages.
4. The invention involves a ring element produced from a sheet metal material, composed of at least two flat material ring segments joined in succession in the circumferential direction and connected, preferably welded, in a production step before the formation of the axial profiling.
5. The flat material ring segments are preferably put together across an engagement zone and welded along edge regions facing each other, with joint contours forming an undercut geometry that preliminarily couples the ring elements in the circumferential direction.
6. The flat material ring segments are cut out, preferably punched out, from a sheet metal material, and the 120° ring segments can achieve a high material saving with only three weld points required for joining together a ring element.
7. The concept of producing the rolling body guide cage from a welded ring segment is suitable for manufacturing radial and axial bearing cages, particularly for groove and angular ball bearings.
8. The method for manufacturing a rolling body guide cage involves producing a ring element from a sheet metal material, obtaining an axial profiling in a forming step, and composing the ring element from at least two flat material ring segments joined in succession in the circumferential direction.
9. The flat material ring segments are preferably welded in the region of a joint formed by these flat material ring segments, with the formation of the weld point preferably performed by laser welding for a high-strength weld point with low welding distortion.
10. The ring segments can be produced with a slight oversize and further cut and calibrated after welding, or cut to their final dimensions in terms of their material

1. The text describes methods and systems for obtaining and processing information related to customer service locations in a telecommunications network. This includes using global satellite positioning (GPS) to acquire latitude and longitude coordinates of a service location, which can be stored in a database and used to assist in determining the location of a customer. The systems and methods can also generate driving directions between service locations to enhance customer service response time.
2. The system includes a technician input device, a transponder system, a protocol server, a technician server, a GPS system, a dispatch system, an address guide system, and a customer records system. The GPS system is used to acquire information associated with a customer service location, while the dispatch system receives and processes information related to service required at customer service locations. The address guide system helps promote valid addresses as customer service locations, and the customer records system stores customer-related information.

1. The invention relates to a system for compensating electromagnetic interfering fields, specifically for magnetic field compensation using two sensors and a digital processor.
2. Current feedback control systems measure the amplitude of interfering fields and calculate control signals for devices generating magnetic fields.
3. Magnetic field compensation systems are used in imaging systems with magnetic fields, such as scanning electron microscopes.
4. Compensation fields should be homogeneous if interfering fields are homogeneous in the range of interest.
5. Pairs of Helmholtz coils are commonly used to generate homogeneous compensation fields.
6. A device for compensating magnetic fields is disclosed in U.S. Publication No 2005/019555A1, using three coil pairs and an analog controller.
7. Systems are available with single coils per space axis, but the compensation region is smaller than with Helmholtz coils.
8. Generally, a single magnetic field sensor is used for measuring the magnetic field, which cannot detect if the magnetic field is homogeneous or inhomogeneous.
9. Problems arise when compensating electromagnetic interfering fields, such as not being able to measure directly at the location of interest and feedback effects between two magnetic field compensation systems.
10. The invention aims to provide a system for compensating electromagnetic interfering fields that can handle homogeneous and inhomogeneous magnetic fields, simulate measuring interfering fields, and equalize feedback effects.

1. The invention describes a method for investigating a sample derived from a biological source using CARS microscopy, where at least one resonance site is furnished in the sample by a bioorthogonal reaction of an intrinsic chemical structure with at least one reaction partner.
2. This method allows for the generation of resonance sites in the sample, which can then be used for image production and the derivation of structural properties of chemical structures containing the resonance sites.

1. The invention provides a system for assessing segmentations from various sources, comparing volume models to identify missing or extra volume elements and measuring their distance from reference volumes.
2. The system can be used for periodic quality assurance of autosegmentation routines, evaluation of those routines with new imaging technology, and training or evaluating clinicians.
3. The apparatus uses an electronic computer to receive first and second electronic files providing data points describing three-dimensional surfaces circumscribing a structure in a human patient.
4. The system converts segmentations to volume models and compares them to identify common, missing, and extra volume elements, outputting a measure of conformance based on the numbers of missing and extra volume elements.
5. The system can evaluate each voxel of a union of the set of voxels of the three-dimensional surfaces on a voxel-by-voxel basis.
6. The system can display a cross-sectional image through the first and second volume models along a user-defined cross-sectional plane, separately identifying the common, missing, and extra volume elements by different colors.
7. The system can receive a third electronic file providing a cross-sectional image of patient tissue at the user-defined cross-sectional plane, displaying the cross-sectional images through the first and second volume models superimposed on the cross-sectional image of patient tissue.
8. The system can provide a histogram showing cumulative missing and extra volume elements as a function of distance ranges.
9. The system can apply different metric methods to different structures automatically or semi-automatically based on common structure descriptors.

1. The invention describes an improved data processing system with a focus on accelerating the execution of floating point operations, specifically the effective subtraction operation.
2. The effective subtraction operation can be accelerated by considering the difference in the arguments of the exponents of the two operands.
3. If the absolute difference is greater than one, a larger operand is identified, and the subtraction operation is performed to ensure a positive resultant quantity.
4. If the absolute difference is less than or equal to one, the alignment of the fractions can be performed without requiring a separate step before performing the subtraction.
5. The detection of the leading logic "1" signal, normalization, and rounding operation can be considered a single time-consuming step.
6. The apparatus implementing the procedures includes a subtraction unit, detection and logic unit, shift and selection logic unit, and selection logic unit.
7. The invention accelerates the effective subtraction operation by calculating a difference between a subset of signal positions of an operand exponent argument and initiating the operation requiring a calculation prior to the determination of the difference between the complete operand arguments.

1. The present invention is a method and system for tracking specimens acquired from patients, aiming to reduce or avoid mislabeling of specimen vials. It involves storing machine-readable codes related to the patient, order, specimen-taker, and specimen container in a relational manner in a computer storage.
2. The method includes reading and dispatching the machine-readable codes from the ID means worn by the patient, the order, the specimen-taker, and the specimen container to a processor of the computer.
3. The processor determines if the patient's code and the order code are related to the same patient and stores the codes in a relational manner in the computer storage. It also generates a signal for acquiring a specimen from the patient and placing it in the container.
4. After receiving a signal that the specimen has been placed in the container, the processor causes an indication thereof to be stored in the computer storage in a relational manner with the codes.
5. The method can further include determining if the specimen container is out-of-date based on the expiration date encoded in the container's barcode and generating an alert signal if it is.
6. The system includes a standalone or networked computer in operative communication with a computer storage and an electronic reading means for reading unique machine-readable codes disposed on the ID means worn by a patient, an order to obtain the one or more specimens from the patient, an ID means worn by a specimen-taker, and a plurality of specimen containers.
7. The electronic reading means is operative for dispatching the machine-readable codes to the processor which stores the machine-readable code for each specimen container to receive a specimen in the computer storage in a relational manner with the machine-readable codes for the patient ID means, the order, and the specimen-taker ID means, and generates a signal to acquire a specimen from the patient and to place the acquired specimen in the container.

1. The invention is a voice-activated distance measuring device for golfers, using GPS technology and voice recognition technology to provide distance and other information verbally to the user. The electronics and software can be incorporated into an article of clothing or a portable device, such as a hat or visor.
2. The device uses commercially available golf course mapping data to convert GPS longitude and latitude coordinates into distance and other factors. It can also accept voice commands or electrical signals for various functions, such as determining pin placement or predicting golf strategy.
3. The device incorporates voice synthesis technology to provide audible output via a loudspeaker or headphone, and can also memorize and compute user input to predict golf course strategy and provide recommendations for future shots.
4. The device may use any GPS system available to measure longitude and latitude coordinates, and may also accept verbal or other data input to build a library of information regarding the golfer's personal shot results.
5. The device may be used for other applications, such as hiking, surveying, hunting, or scuba diving, and may be expanded to include any portable application. It may also be provided with a communications method to upload and download data to a separate personal computer.
6. The device includes a main printed circuit board (PCB) assembly seated in a molded space in a plastic brim stiffener, with a rectangular battery sewn into a compartment on a side of the hat. A transducer, such as a bone conductance vibration sensor, is supported by acoustic dampening material and contacts the wearer's forehead. The plastic brim insert stiffener has a molded space for the PCB assembly and two channels for PCB connector and wiring. The top of the PCB assembly is protected by electrostatic protective padding material and is finished in a fabric similar to the hat body. Bluetooth technology may be used for data transfers, audio server and client functions, short range audio communications, and remote GPS. The device also allows a user to record geographic coordinates of a golf course, including hazards and fairway boundaries, by use of a portable computing device equipped with a global positioning (GPS) device.

1. The present invention is a design rule checking system and method that accurately reports errors for appropriate regions in a system that includes memory and logic circuits.
2. It eliminates false errors caused by design rule checking tools examining regions that are not subject to the same design rules supported by the design rule-checking tool.
3. The method checks whether a logic part of a mask pattern data obeys logic rules and the memory part obeys memory rules, which are logic rules modified appropriately for a memory area.
4. The invention also covers the creation of customized rules appropriate for different types of memory regions based on modifying a standard logic rule.
5. A program can be executed on any number of conventional computing systems for creating such customized rules and performing a design rule check on mask pattern data based on such customized rule sets.
6. The results are categorized in different categories based on where they occur, such as Logic, Bordered Single Port (BDSP) SRAM, Borderless Single Port (BLSP) SRAM, Dual Port (DP) SRAM and ROM groups.
7. The present invention should find significant usage in the semiconductor industry and similar industries where different design rules must be applied to different types of regions on a substrate.

1. This invention is a continuation-in-part of U.S. Patent application Ser. No. 07/790,516 and is supported by the U.S. Government. The invention uses waveguide holograms (WGH) for the controlled illumination of objects with specific illumination requirements, such as display holograms or spatial light modulators (SLM).
2. WGHs are based on thin substrate waveguides, which are characterized by the relationship between the width w of an incident laser beam coupled onto an optical waveguide having a thickness t, controlled by λ, the wavelength of the incident lightwave. Thin substrate waveguides are characterized by t>>λ, allowing for convenient white light illumination and uniform illumination.
3. The inventors have discovered that these thin substrate waveguides can be particularly used for situations requiring controlled illumination, such as illuminating a SLM or hologram. Conventional illuminators require a substantial amount of space, contain several optical elements which are the origin for stability problems, alignment difficulties and obstruction of other light beams. Additionally, for some illumination, it is desired not to flood the object to be illuminated with light, but to pattern the light so it hits only in preselected areas.
4. The invention comprises a thin substrate waveguide optically coupled to a coherent light source, such as a laser, providing extremely high diffraction efficiencies. Non-uniformity of the diffracted wavefront in the direction of propagation can be compensated for by exposing a photographic emulsion to the beam without compensation or by recording the hologram of the waveguide hologram illuminator non-uniformly.
5. The WGH illuminator occupies much less space compared to a conventional lens illumination system and the undiffracted light from a WGH illuminator never enters the instrumentation or the eye of the viewer due to the total internal reflection at the waveguide surfaces. However, with a laser illuminated single-mode waveguide hologram, alignment of the laser beam is critical and there is a time delay across the hologram.
6. Nonuniformity of the diffracted wavefront along the propagation direction is inevitable and

1. The invention describes a method and apparatus for non-destructive testing of dynamoelectric machine rotors, such as those found in electric motors and generators. The apparatus includes a test head with an exciting means to magnetize the rotor, voltage sensing means to generate a voltage signal responsive to the magnetic flux variations, current sensing means to sense the current used to magnetize the rotor, and processing means to determine the resistance and reactance of the rotor.
2. The apparatus may also include skew sensing means to generate an effective skew signal, which the processing means can use to determine the effective electrical skew of the rotor. The test head is designed to resemble a conventional dynamoelectric machine stator, with a core of magnetic material and a set of primary windings that form at least one pair of poles.
3. During a rotor test, an alternating current is supplied to the primary windings, creating an alternating magnetic field in the center cylindrical cavity. The rotor is positioned within the cavity and rotated, inducing voltages and generating magnetic flux. The pick-up coil senses the magnetic flux, generating a voltage signal that is processed to determine the resistance, reactance, and effective skew of the rotor.
4. The invention provides a novel, economical, and reliable method and apparatus for non-destructive testing of dynamoelectric machine rotors, including automatic pass/fail determinations, detailed statistical comparison and evaluation of the measurement results, and identification of defective rotors. The apparatus is designed to be efficient and cost-effective, with a dual fixture system that allows for more efficient testing by reducing delays due to operator set-up time.

1. The text describes a method for securing a computing device by granting access to native resources of an operating system to a managed library with a valid digital certificate, and denying access to a managed application with a digital certificate that only authorizes specific native resource access through the managed library.
2. The method involves using a manager to authorize requests from managed applications to access native system resources through managed libraries, and using a runtime host to access the native system resources.
3. The method also includes receiving a package from a networked computer system, identifying an executable in the package, verifying managed metadata associated with the executable, and storing the verified executable in a digitally signed container.
4. The digital certificate associated with the managed library or executable can be verified by checking a digital signature and comparing it to a public key stored in a secured store.
5. The method can be used in various systems, including mobile devices and gaming platforms, to secure the device and protect digital rights.

1. The invention describes an improved identification card with an internal antenna and integrated circuit chip laminated between two protective, non-rigid layers, which are then laminated between two rigid outer layers. This design aims to protect the electronic components from damage caused by bending stresses and external forces.
   2. The card comprises a core layer of silica-filled polyolefin, at least one antenna and one computer chip electrically connected to it, a bottom sheet of silica-filled polyolefin, and alkyd resin spids containing an anti-binding agent. These layers are encased between two laminate layers using adhesive layers for bonding.
   3. The card's production involves pre-shrinking a core layer, printing indicia, attaching antennae and IC chips, bonding the core layer to a bottom sheet, and laminating the structure with polymer layers. The polymer layers provide mechanical strength and can be applied using heat, pressure, and adhesive layers. The image-receiving layer can be formed using dye diffusion thermal transfer methods or ink-jet printing for personalization.

1. The invention describes a method for implementing a FIFO queue in a functional memory using a tree-shaped data structure.
2. The tree-shaped data structure has nodes with a fixed maximum size, and additions and deletions are made at the first non-full node on the first edge and a leaf node on the opposite edge, respectively.
3. In functional memories, updates require copying only the path from the root to the point of updating, which is logarithmically dependent on the length of the queue.
4. A preferred embodiment includes a separate header node with three elements for the beginning, middle, and end of the queue.
5. Additions and deletions are made to the end and beginning of the queue, respectively, and the tree need not be updated with every addition or deletion.
6. The queue can be inverted in constant time and space by changing the value of an identifier in the header node.
7. The tree structure can also be implemented as a mirror image, with additions made on the right-hand edge and deletions on the left-hand edge.
8. A first preferred embodiment adds a three-element header node to the tree-shaped data structure.
9. The header node includes a leaf node at the end of the queue, a tree of the kind described above for the middle part of the queue, and a leaf node at the beginning of the queue.
10. The invention also includes a bit in the header node indicating which edge constitutes the end and which the beginning of the FIFO queue, allowing for inversion of the queue in constant time and space.

1. The invention provides methods to build embedded EPROM devices using existing IC manufacture technologies, including EPROM devices for DRAM redundancy circuits using existing DRAM technology and EPROM devices manufactured by standard logic technologies that do not require high voltages for operations.
2. The invention utilizes existing circuit elements to build EPROM devices without complicating existing manufacture technologies, such as using DRAM storage capacitors as the coupling capacitors to build floating gate EPROM devices and utilizing transistor properties changed under stress conditions to support EPROM operations.

1. The invention describes a technique for determining the optimum value of feedback gain used in feedback control, which is frequently used in moving automatic guidance vehicles along a predetermined course.
2. The feedback control involves detecting a deviation or error, calculating a correction amount based on the detected error, and correcting the steering angle of the vehicle based on the calculated correction amount.
3. The correction amount can be calculated using P, PI, PD, or PID systems, with the values of feedback gains such as P, I, and D having a significant impact on the feedback control characteristics.
4. The invention aims to provide a method for determining feedback gain that can easily and accurately determine the proper value of feedback gain in a short period of time, regardless of the kind of subject of control.
5. The method involves provisionally determining a predetermined value of feedback gain, executing feedback control using the provisionally determined feedback gain, detecting an error, calculating an evaluation value based on the error, and repeating the process with a new feedback gain value.
6. The evaluation value is calculated based on the length of a curve obtained by plotting the error against the time axis, the integral of the error, or the integral of the absolute value of the error.
7. The method can be used to determine the proportional gain, integral gain, and differential gain, which influence the stability, accuracy, and response of control, respectively.

1. The invention is a zoom lens with a small F-number, high zoom ratio, and standard image angle at the wide angle end, while reducing the size of the entire lens system and maintaining high grade optical performance throughout the entire zooming range.
2. The zoom lens comprises, from front to rear, a first lens unit of positive power for focusing, a second lens unit of negative power having a magnification varying function, a third lens unit of negative power for compensating for the shift of an image plane resulting from the variation of the magnification, a fourth lens unit having a positive lens for making the diverging light beam from the third lens unit almost parallel, and a fifth lens unit having an image forming function and having lenses of positive, negative, positive, negative, positive and positive powers in this order.
3. The zoom lens satisfies specific conditions (1)-(4) for the construction and arrangement of the elements of the fourth and fifth lens units, which ensure good correction of aberrations for high grade optical performance throughout the entire zooming range.
4. The zoom lens can be constructed in various specific forms, including a bi-convex fourth lens unit with a rear surface of strong curvature toward the rear, and a fifth lens unit with six lenses of specific powers and curvatures. Four examples of specific zoom lenses of the invention are provided, with numerical data for the radii of curvature, axial thicknesses or air separations, refractive indices, and Abbe numbers of the glasses of the various lenses.

1. The invention describes a method and device for detecting elementary particles, enabling both measurement of individual particles and integration of count rates.
2. The method involves discharging charge pulses from the detector on the low-voltage side, allowing for individual signal amplification and signal integration.
3. A preferred embodiment proposes amplifying individual signals at low rates and integrating signals at high rates using capacitors and inductive elements.
4. The invention also covers detecting uncharged particles by doping or coating the detector material with a converter material.
5. A further preferred embodiment uses a detector material with fast charge transport at room temperature, such as diamond, for wide signal rate ranges.
